Wednesday, 26 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2913 Wednesday, 26 June 1996 Second Reading Debate resumed from 20 June, on motion by Mr Williams: That the bill be now read a second time. to oppose the Crimes Amendment (ControIIed Operations) Bill. I do not intend to vote against it; I just want to record my concerns. I congratulate the Attorney-General, Daryl Williams. I think that this bilI is an improvement on the one that was put forward by the Australian Labor Party. But it is simply naive if the Attorney-General believes that he has put in safeguards that are not going to see the Commonwealth police become very large-scale drug dealers in this country. The all-pervading power of drugs and the money that is involved have had a very corrosive effect on public confidence. I believe that it has to be tackled as a whole issue, not in this piecemeal way of giving the police ever-increasing powers. It is quite clear to me that the power the police will obtain will be abused. Why do I say that? Because the power of the police is always abused. All power corrupts, and absolute power corrupts absolutely. The West Australian a few days ago had as a headline that Western Australian police are the most corrupt in Australia. I do not believe that. I do not think it is true at all. I think there are elements of corruption which pervade the whole police system and the whole judicial system in Australia. What we need in Australia is not a royal commission-I think the royal commissioners themselves are, sadly, tainted-but a public inquiry into all aspects of the administration of justice. When I look at the justice system in Western Australia, which I know weII, I find it is quite clear that there has been collusion between the prosecution and the police to hide evidence, to falsify evidence, to put forward stuff that they know to be untrue. That, of course, is in total breach of the duty of the prosecution, whose responsibility is to put forward all the evidence and only the evidence. As the High Court has observed, if a prosecutor deviates from this course, he becomes a very powerful unsworn witness for the prosecution. This has happened, sadly, all too often in Western Australia and, I suspect, throughout Australia. I have here a paper entitled, 'Peeling the onion of Long Bay', written by a friend of mine who was actually on remand in Long Bay at the time, under outrageous circumstances. I believe that half a million dollars-his dollars-later, he has been justified. But it is quite clear that there are people in Long Bay because they were set up by the police. The police have awesome powers to fabricate evidence; to set up people. The thing which is driving this, of course, is the corrupting money of drugs. If we are going to do something about this, we have to look at the thing as a whole. I believe that if we were serious about it-and I do not believe for one moment that we are-what we would be doing is legalising and controlling the distribution of these drugs to take the money out. The only way to deal with the big operators, at the big end of town-which this bilI is supposed to attack and simply will not-is to take away the profit margin. If you raise the risk, you raise the margins, and the big operators enhance their profits. I believe that it is

theText: Mr Deputy Speaker, I take this opportunityMC 2914 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 26 June 1996 quite possible to supply drugs on prescription to known addicts at a price which would pay for their cost. After all, most of these drugs are very cheap to produce. It would take away the profit motive. In my view, in that way that industry could be killed stone dead. If there are a few people whose addiction is enhanced by this greater availability, that is a price I would be very happy to pay to do away with the all-corroding effect of drugs on the legal system in Australia. I think it is something that is going to have to be faced up to. I do not see either the government or the opposition facing up to it. It does not just stop at drugs. It pervades the whole legal system. I believe there is evidence of this in the Family Court which, in my view, is an abomination that seeks to be legal. I have a case in Western Australia of a woman who is being unmercifully hounded and harassed by the Family Court. She has lost a fortune, which was a fortune that she brought to the marriage. There is also the matter of the behaviour of the judge in this case. I go through the transcripts, and I get briefings from the civil liberties people, and the behaviour of the judge is beyond belief. The woman has been bashed up in the car park on a couple of occasions, obviously by people who have a vested interest in making sure she does not succeed in her case. One wonders where these things are going to end. I will not be voting against this bill; my vote will be pointless. I want it on the record that I think this bill is dangerous and it sets a dangerous precedent. It will give powers to the Federal Police that will be abused. If anyone thinks that the Federal Police are any different from the state police, I think they are very sadly mistaken. I want it on the record that this bill will not achieve what it sets out to do. There is a possibility that it will in fact do very little, or nothing. There is a risk, in my view, that it will lead to even greater corruption of the police forces, and the judiciary, I might add, than already exists today. WhilstI do not concur with the conclusions he reaches at this stage, nonetheless, the matters he raises are sufficiently serious, I think, for the parliament to continue to keep this particular item of legislation, and other similar items of legislation, under review to ensure that the abuses that he envisages arising from it are nipped in the bud at the earliest possible opportunity. Later, in what will be a fairly short speech on this matter, I will talk more about that. I think it might be useful to go back over some of the background to how this particular bill arises. It arises out of a case in the High Court known as the Ridgeway case. As I understand it, the circumstances of that particular case are that a man named Ridgeway formed an association in prison, in South Australia in the 1980s, with another prisoner called Lee. When Lee was released, he became an informer for the police in Malaysia. Subsequent to that, Ridgeway established contact with Lee, with the intention of importing heroin into Australia. In that context, with Lee as an informer for the Malaysian police, the Malaysian police and Australian Federal Police cooperated in what was called a controlled operation where the police were involved in the importation of heroin in order to obtain convictions, presumably not just of Ridgeway but further up the food chain in relation to drug distribution. Of course, the problem for the police was the relevant section of the Customs Act that provides that any person who imports or attempts to import into Australia any prohibited import to which the section applies shall be guilty of an offence. Ridgeway was convicted but the High Court, on appeal, ultimately upheld his appeal on the basis that evidence associated with the controlled operation should have been excluded under the discretion of the court to

speaker: Mr Sercombe (Maribyrnong) (10.07 A.m.)
theText: The honourable member for Kalgoorlie ( MrWednesday, 26 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2915 exclude evidence on public policy grounds-that is, the court could exclude evidence obtained by unlawful means. The justices of the High Court stated that if law enforcement officials were to be exempted from the law that would be a matter for the parliament and not for the courts. The High Court also made the finding that police have no special immunity from the criminal law and that if criminal offences are committed during an investigation that could taint evidence to the extent that a judge could exclude that evidence. The bill arises from the quite reasonable desire of the former government and this current government to clarify the position and the protections available to law enforcement officers in the sorts of circumstances they found themselves in in the Ridgeway matter. The nature of drug offences and the corrosive influences of that particular sort of activity which the member for Kalgoorlie referred to are well known and the involvement of organised crime in those sorts of activities does require perhaps more novel, innovative ways, including controlled operations, of addressing that sort of crime. So the essential issue before the parliament, as the member for Kalgoorlie indicated, is the nature of the protections that are available if police are to be conferred with some sort of immunity from the criminal law in relation to what would perhaps be, in other circumstances, slightly unconventional actions they may take with respect to investigations in this area. There are three substantial protections in the legislation. One is a protection substantially from police entrapping individuals. Clause 151(2) of the bill, for example, provides that the exemption of law enforcement officers from certain offences does not apply if the conduct of the officer involves intentionally inducing the person targeted to commit an offence and the person would not otherwise have had the intent to commit the offence. Therefore, there is protection against the quite legitimate concern about entrapment that could arise. A further fundamental provision is that the bill makes it quite clear that the discretion of courts to exclude evidence in criminal proceedings or to stay criminal proceedings in the interests of justice is not limited by the operation of this bill. I suppose the other very significant protection that exists for civil liberties and for ensuring that there are some barriers to the sort of police conduct that the member for Kalgoorlie was concerned about is in section ISS of the bill, where the authorising officer, whether that be an AFP officer or a customs officer, needs to report to the minister in question about the action taken; that is, there is a provision that, within three months after a certificate authorising a controlled operation ceases to be in force, the officer must give to the minister a written report stating whether or not the controlled operation authorised by the certificate was carried out. If the operation was carried out, the report must provide considerable detail about the operation, which I do not propose, in the interests of brevity, to go into. Finally, there is a provision in the bill for the minister to table the report before parliament with respect to the controlled operations and some of the circumstances surrounding it. It seems to me on balance that those protections are not only desirable but, I hope, adequate. But they need, as I started off by saying, to be continually reviewed by this parliament to ensure that undesirable consequences do not arise in conferring these sorts of powers on police officers. One of the issues that did arise in debate last year was that the present Attorney-General( Mr Williams) argued, as I understand it, in the House of Representatives that there should be a judicial officer, a judge, involved in the issuing of a certificate to authorise police to carry out controlled operations with immunity from liability. It is interesting that last year the Attorney-General did argue for that particular additional protection. I notice that in the Senate MC 2916 MAIN COMMITIEE Wednesday, 26 June 1996 at the end of last month, when this bill was dealt with, Senator Vanstone, on behalf of the government, indicated her understanding that judges being involved in the criminal investigation process could well invalidate court proceedings at a later date in relation to the matters that the judges had been involved in. That is clearly a very serious matter that the parliament needs to ensure it does not transgress on. In relation to the question of judicial involvement in the issue of certificates, I notice also that Mr Rozenes, of the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions, in giving evidence to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee on this matter last year, had the following things to say: There is no comparison, in my view, between the role that is required to be performed by the grantor of the certificate in this investigative exercise with that which is reposed in the federal court judge, or the magistrate, or whatever it is who gives a warrant for either listening devices, or search warrants, or anything else, where there is a clear requirement that there be balanced the interests of the citizen who is about to have his property turned upside down, his premises invaded, his body samples taken, or his voice listened to, monitored, reported and recorded, on the one hand, and law enforcement requirements on the other. There, there is genuine balancing of competing public interest which requires additional involvement. But even that is currently the subject matter of challenge in the High Court and may, or may not, survive that case. In these situations, there is no competing private right or interest that needs to be balanced against the law enforcement requirement. These are matters of very great constitutional substance which I do not propose to go into in this particular debate, except to say that, because they are of such substance and because the powers that are being conferred on law enforcement officers in these matters are so substantial, I believe there is an obligation on this parliament at some time-and I am not sure whether it is appropriate at this stage to specify the time, but at some reasonable time in the future-to have a look at the way in which these particular provisions have operated to ensure that they are operating satisfactorily, the appropriate balances are in place and there is not abuse by our law enforcement organisations of the trust that has been placed in them. In that context, the question of judicial review ought to be revisited, in my opinion, and that ought to form a basifor a further report to parliament. On balance, this is a bill that, for the reasons I mentioned before-the nature of drug offences, the nature of organised crime involvement in drug offences-does require measures that perhaps some of us would be uncomfortable with in other circumstances. However, it is not a matter that the parliament ought to confer and then forget about. These are powers that the parliament ought to review in the not too distant future to ensure that all the appropriate protections are in place. appearance before the Main Committee. speaker: Mr Slipper (Fisher) (10.19 A.m.)
theText: Mr Deputy Speaker, I apologise for my delayedWednesday, 26 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2917 of those High Court decisions where the court threw back to the parliament a problem which had to be solved through legislative amendment. It ought to be recognised that this bill is a considered response, having been introduced by the previous government and referred to a Senate committee. Suggested amendments were made by that committee and accepted by the new government. We now find ourselves debating the Crimes Amendment (Controlled Operations) Bill 1996. The facts in Ridgeway are actually quite interesting. The case R. v. Ridgeway concerned an operation in which officers of the Australian Federal Police were involved in the importation of a trafficable quantity of heroin. In the High Court, Justice McHugh recited the facts of Ridgeway as follows: [Ridgeway] was released from prison in February 1989. In September and October 1989, he travelled to Singapore under a false name and in breach of his parole conditions. In Singapore, he met Lee and solicited him to import heroin into Australia. Unbeknown to ... [Ridgeway], Lee had become an informer for the Royal Malaysian Police Force. The officer who 'ran' Lee was Thian Soo Chong, an Assistant Superintendent of Police. Lee kept Superintendent Chong informed of his dealings with Ridgeway. In tum, Superintendent Chong alerted Superintendent Butler, an Australian Federal Police Officer stationed in Kuala Lumpur, as to the plans of ... [Ridgeway]. With the knowledge, if not the encouragement of the Australian Federal Police, Superintendent Chong and Lee purchased heroin in north Malaysia for about $4000 on 18 December 1989 for the purposes of delivering it to ... [Ridgeway] in Australia. . . . Arrangements were made by members of the Australian Federal Police and the Royal Malaysian Police Force for Superintendent Chong and Lee to travel to Australia carrying the heroin in a plastic bag inside a tissue box which was in a camera bag. Australian Federal Police officers took steps to ensure that Superintendent Chong-who was carrying the heroin-was not searched or detained by Australian Customs officers. History records that Ridgeway was later arrested by the Australian Federal Police, after having purchased the heroin. Over the years, Mr Deputy Speaker, law enforcement officers in this country have used covert operations to monitor illegal narcotics dealings, to track them through customs and then to apprehend those involved in importation, possession and other offences. The circumstances in this case are, however, quite different. Law enforcement officers themselves were involved in importing heroin for the purposes of apprehending Ridgeway. The Bills Digest has a very effective dissection of the provisions of the bill. When one looks at what is proposed, one has to accept that the legislation we are debating contains an appropriate balance. The High Court decision, therefore, was to the effect that, where law enforcement officials themselves committed an element of the offence for which a defendant is subsequently prosecuted, then as a general rule a court should exercise its discretion to refuse to allow evidence of that element of the offence to be admitted against the defendant. A certain number of the judgesSir Anthony Mason, Mr Justice Deane and Mr Justice Dawson-indicated that, if law enforcement officers are to engage in unlawful conduct in the course of investigations, then a legislative scheme authorising this conduct would need to be established. The genesis of the original bill was, no doubt, the suggestions by those three learned High Court judges that this parliament needed to plug what was obviously an unintended consequence of the law as it existed at the time the Ridgeway facts occurred. The main elements of the bill allow the commissioner, the deputy commissioners and the assistant commissioners of the Australian Federal Police and members of the National Crime Authority to issue certificates authorising a controlled law enforcement operation involving the import, export and/or possession of narcotic drugs. The bill also provides that certain law MC 2918 MAIN COMMITIEE Wednesday, 26 June 1996 enforcement officers, acting in good faith and in the course of duty in relation to an authorised controlled operation, are not criminally liable for certain offences against section 233B of the Customs Act 1901 or offences against sections 10 to 14 of the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Act 1990-that relate to the possession, importation or exportation of narcotics-and associated offences, such as conspiracy, aiding and abetting, and in some cases state and territory offences relating to the possession of narcotic substances and associated offences. The bill also provides that the fact that law enforcement officials took part in, or facilitated, the importation of narcotics prior to the commencement of the bill is not to render evidence of that importation inadmissible, where the importation was made pursuant to a request from the Australian Federal Police to the Australian Customs Service for an exemption from detailed customs scrutiny. The bill also includes procedures which will contain the usage of controlled operations to instances involving the investigation or detection of, or the prosecution of persons for, serious criminal activity. The bill seeks to, in fact, bring in a balanced regime to enable the law enforcement officers of the Commonwealth to carry out their duties. Clearly, one of the great tragedies in Australia is the level of importation of drugs and the devastating effect that drugs have on our youth and on others who have become addicted to them. Consequently, the parliament must always consider community benefit. At times, I am concerned when there are elements of retrospectivity in relation to legislation. Civil liberties should be preserved. It ought to be noted, though, that this particular bill provides a number of very important protections. So the balance has been maintained. Some in the community may criticise the government for not having got the balance exactly right, but I believe that the government is entitled to be praised not only for continuing with this particular piece of legislation but also for incorporating the amendments suggested by the Senate. It ought to be recognised that a person cannot be convicted if, in fact, the person only committed the offence because of the actions of the federal law enforcement officers. So, to be found guilty a person must have been a person who was going to commit an offence anyway. I commend the government and I commend the opposition for continuing to support the government on this issue. As I have said, this is a bill which is supported by both sides of the parliament. It is a bill which, I believe, is in the interests of the Australian community. It is a bill that sends a message to drug traffickers that this country is not going to be soft on drugs or crime. The parliament is seeking to protect Australians from the evil of drugs while ensuring that safeguards are maintained in our law so that people are treated fairly, properly and equitably. I commend the bill to the Main Committee. has existed not so much within the parliament as within the community of those concerned about the way in which we deal with our response to the balance between the right of law enforcement and the protection of civil liberties within our community. As the member for Fisher( Mr Slipper) has rightly indicated, I was minister at the time the High Court brought down its decision in the Ridgeway case. The member for Fisher has set out the background to that litigation, so there is no need to canvass it again. speaker: Mr Kerr (Denison) (10.29 A.m.)
theText: This concludes one of the most passionate debates thatWednesday, 26 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2919 importations or to, in a sense, do nothing and thereby end what was our advice at the time as to what was the most effective way of dealing not against the small players in the international drug trade but rather against the Mr Bigs, the people who were the principal sponsors of the drug trade. Briefly, that dilemma arises because a capacity to involve law enforcement in controlled operations is absent. Whenever the police found a courier with a small amount of some drugor with a large amount of drug-they would be limited in what they could do. In a controlled operation, they seek to enlist the aid of that courier-to 'turn' that courier-to follow those drugs and create an operation designed to sting the principal organiser of the scheme, and to follow the drug trail as far up the line as possible. All the advice I received as minister at the time was that, without the capacity to undertake controlled operations, we would in a sense be limited to arresting the small players in the game. Often they were individuals who were driven to extremity, perhaps by their own addiction or by their own greed, but they were essentially small players in the game against those who are really the professionals, the Mr Bigs of the system. I believed it was important for us to deal with the High Court decision in a way which enabled that law enforcement obligation to be continued. I said at the time, in introducing the Crimes Amendment (Controlled Operations) Bill, that good law enforcement is a citizen's entitlement. I made the point that loss of confidence in law enforcement would lead governments to measures destructive of civil liberties. I indicated that I did not believe that this bill was such a measure and I said that the choice, in my view, was between a society prepared to accept balanced legislation to counter criminals and a society poisoned by the conditions created by those criminals and their activities. I made the point that the bill set out a full and open system of accountability which required reports to the responsible minister and, in turn, reports to the parliament. It is fair to say that those views were certainly not universally accepted by a significant component of those practising at the criminal bar. From their ranks was organised a coalitionI think it was called the Ridgeway coalition-which sought to influence members of this House to oppose the measures which I introduced. There has been within the House, on both sides of the parliament-the coalition parties and our own side-a very heightened awareness of the need to ensure that, in considering this bill, all the civil liberties issues that were raised by the Ridgeway coalition were properly taken into account and included, in so far as they could be, in the considerations that have occurred to date in the construction of this legislation. It pleases me that, after the process of parliamentary scrutiny, a Senate inquiry and a change of government, the bill finds its way back into the House in substantially the same form as I introduced it. It pleases me because it vindicates what I took to be the proper balance at the time; a balance which was then in some contention but which has survived one of the most rigorous processes of examination of any legislation in the parliamentary system. In these remarks, I place on record my particular thanks to Senator Barney Cooney for his work as chair, not only of the Senate committee which examined this legislation but also of the caucus committee on legal and constitutional affairs for many years. He is a person with whom I have had some fierce arguments. He is a person given to strong views, particularly on the subject of civil liberties. In the role that I had to fulfil as Minister for Justice, it was inevitable that, from time to time, we would have a contest of ideas which would require us MC2920 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 26 June 1996 to test each other's assumptions and test the propositions that we were each making in terms of our advocacies to each other. I want to record my very sincere and deep gratitude to Senator Cooney for the work he put into his consideration of government legislation coming before him, both in the caucus committee and in his role as chair of the Senate committee. I believe that the work of this parliament is immeasurably enhanced by parliamentarians of the calibre of Senator Cooney, who have not risen to ministerial rank-and now, with the change of government, are not likely to do so-but whose contribution to this parliament and to Australia generally needs to be recognised on occasions like this. MightI also, because he is sitting next to me at the moment, mention my colleague the member for Banks( Mr Melham), with whom I have also had some fierce contests. It would be no surprise to members of this House to know that the member for Banks took a view contrary to that which I proposed at the time and contested that view fiercely. I believe, also, that this is the place where those arguments can be tested and where the willingness of members to run against the grain of what their own government is doing from time to time is to be valued. There have also been occasions where the member for Banks and I have very much been on the same side. In pulling out materials today for this debate, I inadvertently pulled out a copy of the Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Amendment Bill 1990, which has a similar title to the one we are debating today. I thought I was getting a transcript of what I had said on this legislation earlier, but I pulled this from the computer. That was legislation about which the member for Banks and I had a dialogue with the then Attorney-General, Mr Duffy, which resulted in very substantial improvements to the way in which records of interview were conducted-the videotaping of them and the limiting of time. These were measures which many then involved in law enforcement said would result in a limitation on the ability of law enforcement to do its task, but which, as events have transpired, have not had that effect at all. In fact, they are now universally seen as measures which have improved the accountability of the way the police operate and the effectiveness of policing. Certainly, they have meant that there is far less challenge to the admissibility of confessional evidence, and very much less contest about the way in which police are alleged to have extorted that evidence from people, in improper circumstances. So the member for Banks and I do find common ground on some issues. IfI want to flatter myself, I would say that I took a firmer civil liberties position with respect to that, although we were both on the same side. We succeeded in persuading the then Attorney-General to our point of view, to the benefit, I think, of the Australian community generally. I record my thanks to Barney Cooney and admit my respect for the fierce opposition that was provided to me and to the member for Banks, who managed to hedge me in and cause me enormous frustration and delay, and from time to time some little annoyance at the way in which he was able to contest this field of ideas at the time. I do think it is a little bit of a pity that we were not able to pass this legislation before the expiry of the last term of parliament. We did give it a T category status, which meant the highest priority for legislation, but the then opposition in the Senate declined to avail us of the opportunity of passage of that legislation. The consequence of that is that, although we are now rectifying a situation which needed to be rectified, a number of then pending Wednesday, 26 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2921 prosecutions have failed; a number of major drug importation prosecutions failed in that interim period when this legislation was not in place. I wish to put on record my regret that the then shadow minister, Senator Vanstone, did not grasp the seriousness of this issue and that the coalition was not in a position to support legislation which it now brings again before the House. That delay has led to some unfortunate miscarriages of justice, not in a technical legal sense but in a practical sense, where the evidence against persons alleged to be guilty of crimes could not be brought before the court because of the Ridgeway decision-a matter we are now correcting with respect to future and still pending prosecutions. So that delay has had some serious consequences from the point of view of the community at large. That said, I do join with the member for Fisher to say that I am pleased with the bipartisanship that was ultimately shown. I record that the now Attorney-General, the member for Tangney( Mr Williams), did indicate when this bilI first came before the House his support for it in general terms, a position which is now endorsed by his carriage of this legislation back into the parliament. I think I need say no more. In debates in 1995 I set out my reasons for support of this legislation in some detail and also contested some of the arguments that were then made about the appropriateness of approvals being given by judges, a view I still adhere to in principle, in the sense that I do not believe that with a separation of powers this is an appropriate task to designate to judges, and also in technical legal black-letter law a task which I believe it is incompetent to devolve upon judges, given the decisions of the High Court in recent litigation. This is one of these rare occasions where one can say that after fierce contest one feels vindicated. I am delighted that I am able to stand here and say that I initiated this legislation. It has undergone an ordeal of fire. It has passed that ordeal and I believe that it has passed it to the benefit of the Australian community. It is a matter we will be endeavouring to change, to reform, because we consider that not to be in the best interests of a democratic and properly functioning House of Representatives. As a former member of the Procedure Committee, I have some serious concerns about it, having spent some time considering it when the Main Committee was being debated as a proposal of the Procedure Committee-in other words, during its formative debates. speaker: Mr Filing (Moore) (L0.43 A.m.)
theText: I rise to speak briefly to the Crimes AmendmentMC2922 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 26 June 1996 which is often portrayed by the media as being the crime capital of the Western world. It made some interesting comments on a survey that was conducted by the ministry of justice in the Netherlands in 1992. It says: America is no more criminal than other countries. According to an international crime survey carried out by the Ministry of Justice in the Netherlands in 1992, America is not obviously more criminal than anywhere else. You are more likely to be burgled in Australia or New Zealand; you are more likely to be robbed with violence in Spain; you are more likely to be robbed without violence in Spain, Canada, Australia and New Zealand. Perhaps this next part is not strictly related to drug trafficking, but it adds: You are more likely to be raped or indecently assaulted in Canada, Australia or Western Germany. I make these comments because Australia's crime statistics are becoming a matter of serious concern. It is quite clear that the community is now demanding greater concentration on the part not only of their state governments, who have the immediate jurisdiction for criminal investigations, but also-in relation to drug trafficking and all of its 'subsidiary industries'-on the part of the Australian federal government. This is because, in the first instance, the Australian federal government has responsibilities in relation to the importation and subsequent trafficking of narcotics across state jurisdictions and the like. As a member of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Crime Authority for six years-and I note that the member for Banks( Mr Melham) was a former colleague of mine on that committee-I can say that we have spent inordinate amounts of time looking at the way in which the National Crime Authority has been somewhat confounded in the past, due to operational requirements relating to joint operations with state police forces and the Australian Federal Police. We have also looked at, for instance, the very important report that was tabled a couple of years ago on Commonwealth law enforcement agencies and future criminal trends, and at the resourcing of Commonwealth law enforcement agencies in the future as a consequence. As a continuing member of the Joint Standing Committee on the National Crime Authority, it is my view that some of the cuts foreshadowed in recent times for the forthcoming federal budget are a matter of some concern, whereas there is no doubt that, owing to the fiscal irresponsibility of the previous Labor administration, there is a substantial requirement for cost cutting on the part of the federal government-a matter that a vast majority of the community would no doubt agree with. The overwhelming victory by the coalition government bears testimony to the fact that there is a perception and a belief that the spending of the Commonwealth government was out of hand. Nonetheless, across-the-board spending cuts are dangerous in that they are often blind to the more important necessities, particularly in areas such as this, where we have national criminal investigation agencies-the AFP and the NCA-which are facing, and are already undertaking, cuts to their administrative operations that are going to impinge on the fight against crime, drug trafficking and the insidious influence of organised crime within our community generally. These are matters of concern, and I have indicated them already to the Attorney-General( Mr Williams). This is something that I feel very strongly about. In particular, coming as I do from the state of Western Australia-as does the Attorney-General-I am conscious that we are faced with particular problems that are, let us say, a consequence of our geography, the most notable feature of which is the large coastline of Western Australia. Wednesday, 26 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC2923 There is believed to be, through Western Australia's frontier-our international frontier-a regular annual importation into the country of drugs of some $1 billion in value. For instance, it was calculated in recent times that in a 100-kilometre radius of Geraldton some $300 million worth of drugs were smuggled into Australia in the past few years. I might add that, at the same time, the Comptroller-General of Customs at the Geraldton wharves was complaining that he had no video surveillance of activity on the wharves; a surveillance which I would have thought would have been absolutely critical to any law enforcement operation that was really going to have an effect on the importation of drugs into our community. I made those comments at the beginning because a lot of offences that are occurring within our community today-particularly break and enter, stealing and robbery-are mostly drug related. Often, addicts are stealing property from ordinary citizens to feed their habits. Our state police forces are under extraordinary stress as a consequence. We know that in recent years the various state governments, particularly when they have been coalition governments, have had their own budgetary requirements to cut costs. We have seen reductions in real terms of budgets for the various state police forces, and in particular this impinges on the opportunities for full-scale joint operations with Commonwealth law enforcement agencies. So there is a compounding effect of the cuts on the federal scene, the cuts on the state scene and the fact that we are witnessing an explosion of drug trafficking within our community, stimulated to some extent by our proximity to the South-East Asian region. I was privileged to be able to attend a recent conference in Sydney, organised jointly by the National Crime Authority and the Australian Federal Police, on organised crime within the South-East Asian and Asian region. I was fascinated to hear some of the comments of law enforcement officers from our neighbouring countries. The former minister would know that I have been a critic at times because there were some restrictions placed on exchange of information between our national law enforcement agencies and some of their counterparts overseas as a consequence of policy decisions by the Australian federal government which I believed were quite extraordinary under the circumstances. One of those was that, where a jurisdiction overseas had, for instance, capital punishment on its statute books for a particular offence and where a person had been apprehended and interviewed and charged over an offence that involved a capital offence, Australia would restrict the information that would be passed on about this person's antecedents and possible connections, as a consequence of an Australian point of view on the relative severity of that penalty. In my view, that is a reverse form of chauvinism which implies that Australia's criminal code and its criminal justice system are somehow superior to those of other jurisdictions in our region. But it was in fact an impediment to the free exchange of information that would help the fight against organised crime and in particular against organised drug trafficking, in my view the greatest criminal evil facing our nation at present. I am sure that anyone who is a parent of children in today's community knows only too well the incipient fear at all times of the threat that their child may one day indulge in or experiment in drug consumption. In recent times we have seen some quite horrific stories where younger children-younger juveniles, let us say-are becoming involved in drug consumption at an earlier age. In fact, I recollect that when I was a police officer in Western Australia between 1979 and 1987 I came across one instance of amphetamine consumption by a Western Australian offender in my contacts. But, not that many years later, we were MC 2924 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 26 June 1996 seeing instances where high school students were consuming amphetamines by injection on school premises. This is a quite extraordinary development; a trend that has to be reversed and a trend that requires not only sustained funding for our federal law enforcement agencies but also an increase which recognises the compounding, cascading effect throughout the community of this great evil that drug trafficking represents. At the beginning I mentioned some of my concerns and those of some of my Independent colleagues in relation to the processes of the House of Representatives. We have seen at the beginning of the parliamentary session a statement, following on from statements made during the election campaign, regarding the changes to our processes to make the House of Representatives a better functioning, more relevant and more democratic place in which the members can represent their constituents to the best effect. I took these statements in good faith, as I am sure many others did, and I believe that these changes are absolutely critical. We must ensure at all times that, where the executive is misusing the processes of the House of Representatives, they must be resisted by all members-not just Independent members but all members-who value the hard-fought rights of the representatives in the chamber as representatives for their constituents. We can do no more for our constituents than ensure their rights are preserved. We know that, in recent years, there has been a very strong perception that not only is the debate in the House of Representatives largely irrelevant to the processes of government but also the government regards it in that vein and treats it accordingly. In relation to this bill, in relation to other bills, in relation to the processes of the House of Representatives and in relation to the processes of the Main Committee, the House must assert the rights of its members over the rights of the executive to ensure that it is more relevant and answerable to the people. I can recollect sitting as a member of the coalition opposition and saying the same things. Unfortunately, as an Independent member, I am now seeing some of the traits of executive superiority being asserted over the rights of the members of the House of Representatives yet again. I hope that we can hold or push that back, because, at the end of the day, it suits everybody that that should take place. We must see the rights of members of the House of Representatives restored to their rightful place. As a consequence, last sitting week, my colleague the member for Curtin( Mr Rocher) moved that a number of the bills be proceeded with further in the House of Representatives chamber. I will be making a similar move shortly, in relation to the next bill. But I wanted to emphasise those points in the first instance, just to demonstrate why we are taking on this particular responsibility in the House of Representatives and in the Main Committee and why we believe that the reforms that were proposed by the Prime Minister( Mr Howard), in good faith, should be undertaken all the way through to the end of their meaning. Of course, one of those reforms related to the independent status of the Speaker of the House of Representatives, something that I am sure the member for Calare( Mr Andren), other members and I view as being extremely important. As a consequence, we are anxious to ensure that the House of Representatives supports that role and ensures that it is enhanced in all of its activities. Finally, I think the bill is one, as the member for Fisher( Mr Slipper) indicated, which is deserving of bipartisan support. But I want to repeat those words of caution I said at the beginning. These amendments are all very well. But, at the end of the day, when our national law enforcement agencies are suffering substantial cuts in their operational ability, a lot of Wednesday, 26 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2925 these sorts of changes-as noteworthy and as appropriate as they are-are less significant, because the agencies are less able to use the tools, the abilities and the resources, because of the infringements forced on them by the cuts to their budgets. I commend the bill to the Main Committee. who have taken part in this debate today. In summing up, there are a couple of responses I would like to make. The honourable member for Banks( Mr Melham) referred to the possible dangers involved when police are empowered to authorise otherwise unlawful conduct by police. The accountability package in the bill will prevent abuse of the process. Frankly, if we are to have any hope of bringing major narcotics traffickers to justice, we must give police adequate powers. Narcotics trafficking is big money. It is a high risk industry. In such an environment, the possibility for attempts to corrupt police will always exist. But the way to prevent corruption is not to deny police the powers contained in this bill. It is to build in effective accountability mechanisms and safeguards against the abuses of power. The power to authorise controlled operations will lie with 12 senior experienced law enforcement officers: nine in the AFP and three in the NCA. These officers will be responsible to the parliament and the public for the conduct of these operations. Openness and accountability are central to the framework established by the bill. The bill requires a detailed report to be made to the minister at the time of the decision to authorise an operation. That is, of course, contained in the proposed section I5R. The bill will also require a detailed report to be made about what happened during and after the operation; that is contained in section I5S. In addition, the Australian Federal Police are subject to a strict disciplinary regime and are subject to disciplinary and criminal penalties for misconduct under both the AFP Act and the AFP (Discipline) Regulations. I turn now to the comments made by the member for Kalgoorlie ( Mr Campbell). He said that the proposed power will encourage corruption. Frankly, if we are to have any hope of bringing narcotics traffickers to justice, we must give police the adequate powers. The way to prevent corruption is not to deny the police these powers. Commissioner Fitzgerald, in the report of the Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct, concluded that: The true choice may be between the society altered by legislative or executive action to the extent which is necessary to hamper the misuse of civil privileges by criminals, or a society altered by those criminals and their activities ... It might be preferable to have a limited qualification of rights so that they can be enjoyed in the freer atmosphere of a fairer more honest and honourable society. I should also add that an officer who sought to deal in narcotics outside the course of duty would face the normal penalties for narcotics trafficking. Federal law enforcement officers are already subject to a strict disciplinary regime. Australian Federal Police officers, who will play the leading role in most operations, are subject to disciplinary and criminal penalties for misconduct under both the AFP Act and the AFP (Discipline) Regulations. AFP officers are employed on contract and can be summarily dismissed in cases of misconduct. theText: Minister for Administrative Services) (10.58 a.m.)-I thank all thoseMC 2926 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 26 June 1996 the Senate. The outcome of the debate was that the Democrats, who had pressed amendments to require judicial authorisation, were persuaded that the proposal was unwise and withdrew the amendments. The difficulties with the proposal were well expressed by Senator Cooney in the debate on 29 May when he said: I think no judge should be brought before a court and cross-examined as to why he or she believes that a person is likely to commit an offence. The honourable member for Maribyrnong also proposed that a parliamentary committee should review the provisions after some years. The legislation will be reviewed by the courts very soon after it commences operations. There are prosecutions on foot at the moment that will almost certainly result in the testing of provisions. This is a more effective and more immediate form of scrutiny than that which is proposed by the honourable member. The honourable member is also most likely aware that the High Court is at present considering a case which involves debate about the propriety of judges performing non-judicial functions. I refer to the case involving argument about the appointment of Judge Jane Mathews to conduct the Hindmarsh Bridge inquiry. This is an emerging issue and it would be premature to establish a review mechanism now. It is possible that some kind of major review, possibly by the ALRC or by a parliamentary committee, will be needed once the issues have fully emerged. The honourable member for Moore( Mr Filing) made great play of the possible budget cuts to the NCA. He would know that I can provide no details of any budget proposals involving the NCA or any other agency. Obviously, we must wait for details of the budget which will be delivered on 20 August. However, any cuts to the NCA will in any event be considered in the light of the functions which are performed by the range of Commonwealth and state law enforcement agencies which have a role in the struggle against the importation of illicit narcotics. The previous government's report, the Review of Commonwealth Law Enforcement Arrangements, identified the need to 'eliminate perceived duplications of roles that existed between the NCA and the AFP.' This would offer the opportunity to make savings without an effect upon the performance of functions. The honourable member must not assume that any cuts to the funding of the NCA, if in fact there are any, will necessarily have a negative effect upon the efficiency of the struggle against crime and the importation of illicit narcotics in particular. Proposed section 15U will require the tendering of the certificate. During the debate in the Senate an amendment to insert a new section 15U, which deals with the tendering of evidentiary certificates, was carried. Such a provision was not included in the bill presented by the government because it was felt to be unnecessary. It is inevitable that the fact of a controlled operation will be apparent to the defence in any trial depending upon such evidence. The defence will then have the right to oppose the admissibility of the evidence by challenging the authorisation procedure. This would be done in most cases by way of a voir dire. However it does not damage the bill to include specific requirements that the prosecution tender the certificate thus putting the defence on notice that evidence resulting from a controlled operation will be adduced. Section 15U is somewhat imperfect in that the section, on its face, requires that a certificate authorising a controlled operation is to be tendered in evidence in 'a prosecution for an offence against section 233B of the Customs Act 1901'. Needless to say, many prosecutions for Wednesday, 26 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC2927 offences under section 233B of the Customs Act will arise which do not depend on any evidence gathered through a controlled operation. In many cases there will be no certificate to present. My department is confident that the court will apply common sense principles of interpretation to the operation of section 15U and will not require the tendering of a certificate in a trial where no controlled operation is being conducted. The requirement to tender the certificate will arise only in those cases where evidence is to be led by the prosecution which has been obtained through the conduct of a controlled operation. I again thank honourable members for their valuable contributions to this debate. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Bill-by leave-reported to the House without amendment. Quite frankly, I find it quite extraordinary that he has expressed those concerns but now wants to obstruct the passage of the legislation, which is supported by both the government and the opposition, to give the Commissioner of the AFP very necessary powers to deal with police corruption. His actions are inconsistent with his words. I therefore present the explanatory memorandum of the bill and proceed to the second reading. Vigilance against police corruption is an ongoing issue for Australian governments and the public at large. The more important provisions of this bill are focused on ensuring that the Australian Federal Police remains corruption free. A similar bill lapsed earlier this year due to the federal election. The government has decided to introduce a bill in a similar form to provide the necessary armoury to combat corruption within the Australian Federal Police. Members will be aware that the royal commission into the New South Wales Police Service has uncovered distressing instances of corruption and other serious misconduct. Such abuse of power and of the community's trust can never be tolerated in any police service. I know all members were distressed to hear that serving and former members of the Australian Federal Police have been implicated in corruption and other reprehensible behaviour. The government and the administration of the Australian Federal Police are strongly committed to ensuring that it is never debilitated by a culture of corruption and misconduct.

theText: The comments made today by the honourable member for Moore have basicallyMC2928 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 26 June 1996 The institutional culture of a police force is of vital importance to a community. A police force stands at the threshold of the criminal justice system and is in effective control of the enforcement of the criminal law. Each police officer has an extensive authority over all other citizens, coupled with a wide discretion over its exercise. Subsequent stages in the criminal justice process, including courts and prisons, are largely dependent on the activities of police services and will inevitably be affected by their deficiencies. The Commonwealth is, of course, particularly dependent on the integrity and efficiency of the Australian Federal Police. First, it is the principal agency for the general enforcement of the Commonwealth's criminal laws. It provides a vital link in effective cooperation with international law enforcement bodies. It is essential that the Australian Federal Police maintains the confidence of these bodies as well as the public's confidence. In 1989, the parliament, with the support of all parties, substantially amended the Australian Federal Police Act 1979. The reforms were designed, in part, to introduce a new and unique employment scheme which would inhibit the occurrence of patterns of corruption uncovered in other police services. One aspect of these reforms was the replacement of tenure with a system of fixed term appointments. Another aspect was providing the commissioner with chief executive powers in relation to appointments within the Australian Federal Police, including the power to end the appointment of any police member or civilian staff member. One of the principles underlying this employment scheme is that the commissioner should have a clear and specific responsibility for the integrity and operational efficiency of the Australian Federal Police. Naturally, the scheme also envisaged that the commissioner should have the powers and authority necessary to fulfil these responsibilities. At present, the commissioner's power to terminate the appointment of members or staff members of the Australian Federal Police is subject only to two exceptions. The current legislation states that the commissioner must not make use of this power merely because a disciplinary charge has been or could be laid or a court has convicted or found the person guilty of a criminal offence. These exceptions were provided in order to separate the Australian Federal Police's disciplinary processes-which can result in dismissal as a penalty for a disciplinary offencefrom the commissioner's general power to end a person's appointment. In practice, the limitations on the commissioner's power of dismissal can lead to situations which are clearly inconsistent with the policy aims of the AFP employment scheme. For example, it is not clear that the commissioner can terminate the appointment of a member of the Australian Federal Police even if the member admits publicly that he or she is guilty of corruption or other serious reprehensible behaviour. To dismiss that person from the Australian Federal Police, it might be necessary for the commissioner either to invite the member to resign voluntarily or to initiate disciplinary proceedings. The commissioner's hands could be equally tied if the person were to be convicted of serious criminal offences by a court. The government believes that this situation is unsatisfactory. Corruption in a police service can seriously undermine the professional self-respect and morale of the decent and honest police who comprise the majority of members. It can also seriously diminish public confidence in the affected police service, something that may now be apparent in respect of the New South Wales Police Service. Immediate and effective action may be the only way to minimise the harm. On occasions, it will not be desirable to wait for lengthy disciplinary or court proceedings to be finally resolved before taking action. Wednesday, 26 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2929 The proposed amendments will remove the limitations on the commissioner's powers of dismissal which relate to disciplinary offences and criminal convictions. The intention is to give the commissioner a broader and more effective power to end an appointment where the commissioner has lost confidence in a person's suitability for continued employment in the Australian Federal Police. The amendments will, in particular, permit the commissioner to act quickly and decisively to end the appointment of a person where the commissioner believes on reasonable grounds that there has been corruption, serious abuse of power or serious dereliction of duty. While the government believes it is necessary in the public interest for the commissioner to have a wide discretion to end appointments, it also recognises that the employment rights of individual members and staff members within the Australian Federal Police should also be protected. Currently, members and staff members are protected in two ways in the event that they are retired by the commissioner before the end of their terms of appointment. Firstly, people who are retired may seek judicial review by the Federal Court of the commissioner's decision to end their appointments. Secondly, retired people are entitled to compensation for the lost part of their appointments. As this bill will widen the scope of the commissioner's powers to end appointments, the government believes it is also reasonable to extend to members and staff members additional remedies against the possibility that the commissioner's power might be exercised unfairly or unreasonably. The government has been at pains to find an appropriate balance between the public interest in maintaining a corruption free Australian Federal Police and the rights of the individual member or staff member who may be retired early either because of allegations of corruption or for other reasons, such as inefficiency. In particular, in reconsidering this bill, I focused on the need for appropriate safeguards to protect innocent members and staff members. The government has decided that, in addition to the existing protective measures I have outlined, individual members and staff members who have their appointments terminated early will also have access to merit reviews before the Industrial Relations Commission and the Industrial Relations Court. At present, the Australian Federal Police are excluded from those unlawful termination provisions by the industrial relations regulations. Honourable members will no doubt be aware that, under the government's industrial relations reforms, it is proposed that the Industrial Relations Court be abolished and for the industrial relations jurisdiction to be conferred instead on the Federal Court. The government intends to repeal the relevant industrial relations regulation, subject to transitional and savings provisions, with effect from the date that the amendments in this bill come into force, and that is 28 days after royal assent. The bill makes one exception to the opening of the unfair dismissal remedies to the Australian Federal Police. This is where serious misconduct is involved. The bill provides that, where a person's appointment has been ended because of their conduct or behaviour, the commissioner may make a declaration that the conduct or behaviour amounts to serious misconduct and that the serious misconduct is having, or is likely to have, a damaging effect on professional self-respect or morale within the Australian Federal Police or on its reputation with the public or with an Australian or overseas government or law enforcement agency. Serious misconduct is defined in the bill to mean corruption, serious abuse of power, serious dereliction of duty or any other serious reprehensible behaviour. Where a declaration of this MC 2930 MAIN COMMITIEE Wednesday, 26 June 1996 kind is made, the person who has been retired will be excluded from the operation of the Industrial Relations Act provisions concerning unlawful dismissal, and will not be able to obtain merit review. Such persons, however, will retain the present right to compensation for their early retirement and to seek judicial review of the commissioner's declaration, as well as the decision to end their appointment. Also, a person subject to a declaration of serious misconduct will be able to seek a statement of reason in relation to the commissioner's decision to make the declaration. However, where the reasons would disclose information that would not be in the public interest to disclose-for example, operationally sensitive information such as the identity of informants or current investigations-the Attorney-General may, in the public interest, issue a certificate under subsection 14(1) of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977 preventing disclosure of that information. This solution reaches an appropriate balance between the public interest in maintaining a corruption free Australian Federal Police and the rights of the individual. As I have indicated, the commissioner will be able to make a declaration only where the commissioner believes on reasonable grounds that there has been serious misconduct by the person who is retired. It is also necessary that the commissioner believes that the serious misconduct is actually damaging, or is likely to damage, the Australian Federal Police in one of the ways I have described. Clearly, these are special circumstances. They are circumstances in which immediate action by the commissioner is needed to maintain the internal integrity or the public reputation of the Australian Federal Police, and where it is not appropriate that an outside tribunal may be able to remake the commissioner's decision. The amendment will permit the commissioner to make a declaration either before or after the behaviour or conduct in question becomes widely known. This is to allow the commissioner to act to pre-empt the threatened damage to the morale or reputation of the Australian Federal Police. The bill also contains several minor amendments concerning two separate matters. One group of amendments is intended to give the Governor General the power to authorise the commissioner and the deputy commissioners to appoint or promote persons as commissioned officers with the Australian Federal Police. At present the legislation permits the Governor General to give this authority only to the commissioner. The new arrangements are administratively more convenient. The amendments allow for appropriate safeguards. The second group of amendments deals with the disciplinary obligations of staff members when granted special leave of absence for service with an industrial association. The effect is to extend the existing provisions which deal with members to staff members, as well. I commend the bill to the Main Committee. I think, that the poor old government does not have much on its plate in the way of legislation so it has been picking up, in the main, the legislation of the previous government, and that is what this bill basically is. Apart from some minor procedural amendments that were made to the 1995 bill, this bill is substantially the bill that the Labor party introduced before the election, and the party supports wholeheartedly an expedited passage of the bill. Confidence in law enforcement is ultimately the difference between a civil and peaceful society and complete lawlessness. For this reason, the confidence of the Australian people in the integrity of their police force is of vital importance. It behoves the elected representatives of the Australian people to support, defend and express their confidence in the police force. I put on the public record my support for that view. Members of parliament, both state and federal, should be seen to be supporting the police force in its operation and, I think, in both a moral and a personal way, should help the police to enforce the laws that are created by these parliaments. This, of course, includes ensuring that the police force remains corruption free and that it has the ability to quickly respond to any suggestion of corruption or serious misconduct. This bill is aimed at avoiding a culture of corruption and misconduct in the Australian Federal Police. While the Wood royal commission in New South Wales has uncovered disturbing allegations of corruption in that state's police force, present and former members of the Australian Federal Police have also been implicated and named before the commission. Against that backdrop, this bill empowers the Australian Federal Police Commissioner to dismiss police officers in cases of corruption or serious misconduct. Until now, there has been some doubt as to whether an officer of the Australian Federal Police could be sacked, even if they had been found guilty of a criminal charge. The officer would need to resign voluntarily or face disciplinary hearings, but the ability of the Australian Federal Police to move swiftly and effectively was compromised. This is an attitude of the public sector, and this bill really brings about quite a dramatic change to that attitude. Now the commissioner will be able to deal with any suggestion of wrongdoing in the Australian Federal Police and restore public confidence with decisive action. The bill will provide some limited access to the unfair dismissal provisions of the Industrial Relations Act, except in cases of corruption, serious abuse of power or serious dereliction of duty. While protection from unfair dismissal may be fair enough for most employees, clearly there must be a different set of rules for the police force. The community demands that swift action be available to dismiss police officers with a proven tainted record. Can you imagine what would happen if the former Labor government's unfair dismissal laws applied to the police force? In the case of these unfair dismissal laws, we have seen cases where workers have stolen, lied, accessed confidential files for personal use and been abusive to clients and seriously disloyal to the employer, and the Industrial Relations Court has reinstated them with back pay and compensation. As members of the former government would understand, the Howard government does not agree with this unfair dismissal procedure and is very unhappy with the consequences: it was about $7,000 for every dismissal. It was better, in most cases, for the employer to pay the money because that is what it would finally cost, no matter what the reality of the case was, because of the legality of the unfair dismissal arrangements. The Australian Federal Police and the state police forces need to be well equipped to respond to any suggestion of serious misconduct with very swift action, and not have to put up with the unfair dismissal procedures. For minor allegations, the police officers will be protected by the unfair dismissal provisions in the new Industrial Relations Act, where it is appropriate. The Australian Federal Police is the principal law enforcement agency of the Commonwealth; it is the federal force in charge of policing breaches of the laws of the Commonwealth. Aside from investigations relating to offences against Commonwealth law, the Australian Federal Police provides a community policing role in the ACT. The headquarters are located in Canberra, with regional commands in states and territories. There are nearly 3,000 members of the force in 31 Australian offices and 15 overseas bureaus. There are also Australian Federal Police representatives attached to Interpol headquarters. Members of the force have been involved in the UN peacekeeping operations in Cyprus, Mozambique, Cambodia and Somalia. The operations of some aspects of the Australian Federal Police are quite extensive. The operational priorities of the Australian Federal Police are to provide the best in prevention, detection and investigation of criminal offences against the Commonwealth, with particular emphasis on organised crime and strategic intelligence, and to provide leadership in the Australian law enforcement effort. The federal police has cooperative relationships with the National Crime Authority, the Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board and state police agencies. I thought that at times, particularly in remote areas of Australia, videotaping would pose significant problems of access, facilities, distance and time involved after apprehending a suspect, interviewing, and going through the further processes that are applicable under the relevant statutes. This, I believe, has now proved to be a significant advantage. It has enhanced police work. It has also meant, in the context of prosecution of cases in the courts, that the courts are able to see the accused at the point when they are being interviewed by the police in a way that often reveals more about them than mountains and mountains of written or oral evidence could possibly do. I would say from my discussions with other police officers, particularly the ones I consider to be thoughtful about these processes, that I believe that they are all in agreement with the changes that have been brought in, in particular the changes relating to videotaping of interviews. Also, videotaping is a critical part of the element of visibility, which I mentioned earlier. It means that people can see the process, with the benefit of hindsight to a certain extent. It is there on the record in physical evidence, visual and in sound. That is something that permits the courts to have a greater scrutiny of police practices and police behaviour. I reiterate some of the comments made earlier in relation to cuts. But, if we are going to have a police force and an Australian Federal Police that is going to be effective, it has to be as independent as possible. In other words, within the communal justice system it must be able to exercise its statutory responsibilities in a way that is consistent with the basic principles of a proper, responsive criminal justice system. Also, it is not to be interlinked or merged in joint standing facilities with other agencies. That is something I have criticised in the past; it is something from the former Minister for Justice that I have criticised. I felt that the joint standing operations between the NCA and the Australian Federal Police were to the detriment of both organisations. I believe that each should be self-standing and clearly separated so that they are clearly answerable in their own ways to their own particular statutes and, at the end of the day, via the minister, to the parliament. Our processes are critical to a criminal justice system. It is fair to say that in the past, particularly in New South Wales, if the legislators had been more diligent in looking over the operations of the New South Wales Police, we would have had a different situation. There were all sorts of allegations in the 1950s, the 1960s, the 1970s and the 1980s in relation to the interlinking of corrupt behaviour in the police and some of the political figures of the times. But it is fair that we must ensure that the police force's activities, its responsiveness, its efficiency, its effects, and its method of operations are as clearly visible as possible so that the community can see, to their satisfaction or otherwise, that they are getting a service that they deserve. I said at the beginning that you get the police force you deserve. If we have got police forces that are less than satisfactory, we have to look back at our own community and we have to make the decision to reform the police forces in ways that are consistent with what we ask Wednesday, 26 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2939 the community to do themselves. After all, police officers are human beings. A vast majority of them around the country perform their duties honestly and decently, as best they can. In many cases, as we saw recently with the Port Arthur massacre and in other instances, they go far beyond the call of duty to provide services that many other citizens would probably find themselves completely unable to do. We ask them to do that on our behalf. In order to ensure that they have the standing in the community, we have got to ensure that they are able to work in the sorts of administrative and organisational settings that enhance their honesty and their commitment to their work, and at the end of the day give the public the satisfaction that it is getting the best possible police service that it deserves. I commend this bill to the Main Committee. As I mentioned earlier, it is important that this bill is passed as soon as possible. As a consequence I have refrained from referring it back to the main chamber. members who have contributed to the debate on this legislation this morning. I palticularly thank the members of the opposition for their support. I would also like to thank the honourable member for Moore( Mr Filing) for not proceeding with his motion regarding this bill. I trust that the bill will now have a speedy passage in its remaining stages. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Bill-by leave-reported to the House without amendment. Second Reading Debate resumed from 22 May, on motion by Mr Sharp: That the bill be now read a second time. designed to increase the size of the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority by two: the present number of four lay members will be increased to six. The authority's Chief Executive Officer, Mr Leroy Keith, is also an ex officio member of the board. The bill is also designed to empower the minister to appoint one of the members of the board as a deputy chair of the board. Briefly, the background to this legislation has to be seen in the context of the tragic disaster of the Monarch Airlines crash at Young in mid-1993 and the subsequent Bureau of Air Safety Investigation report into that crash. That led to the then Minister for Transport, Mr Laurie Brereton, announcing that the government intended to separate the commercial and safety regulatory functions of the former Civil Aviation Authority into two separate bodies. The legislation to do so was announced by the then minister on 28 March 1995 and was passed by the parliament a couple of months later. As a result of that legislation, two separate bodies-Airservices Australia and the Civil Aviation Safety Authority-were created by the parliament.
