speaker: Mr Tanner (Melbourne) (11.57 A.m.)
theText: The Civil Aviation Amendment Bill 1996 isMC 2940 MAIN COMMITIEE Wednesday, 26 June 1996 sector, are the questions associated with the safety regulatory functions performed by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority as it now is. The new board of the authority took office on 1 July 1995. The four lay members who were appointed then and who are still in office are: the chair of the board, Mr Justice Bill Fisher, who is Chief Judge of the New South Wales Industrial Court as well; Ms Gaby Hollows, who is a consumer advocate; Dr Claire Pollock, who is a systems safety expert; and Mr Geoff Molloy, who is a former Qantas pilot. As I indicated, the director, Mr Leroy Keith, is an ex officio member of the board. Shortly after coming to office, the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp, endeavoured to force the four members of the board to resign. He wrote letters to them individually seeking their resignations. He rang each of them individually seeking their resignations and at at least one meeting, and possibly more, collectively spoke to the board members asking them to resign. The only reason that he gave at that point was, and I quote, 'ThatI have obligations to other people.' Given that the board members had been in office for only about nine months, that there had been no substantive complaints levelled against them, and that the issues which arose from, for example, the BASI investigation into the Monarch disaster, predated their period on the board, it was rather a peculiar performance by the minister. In fact, he subsequently admitted that it would not go down as one of his best performances. He did point out, correctly, that the coalition policy prior to the election was to increase the amount of aviation expertise, or direct aviation industry background, represented on the board. This was a position that was strongly supported by the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association, which strongly supported the coalition, and Mr Sharp in particular, during the election campaign. AOPA is headed by Mr Dick Smith and Mr Boyd Munro who is present here in the gallery today. It is fair to say that AOPA has been in substantial conflict with the former CAA and now its successor, CASA, over a wide range of safety regulation issues. A number of those issues have already been canvassed or dealt with by the minister. This bill has emerged ultimately because of the minister's failure to shift the existing board members. It is very disturbing that in presenting his ministerial statement to the parliament yesterday the minister made completely unsubstantiated statements to the effect that the existing board members,were, 'putting their own interests ahead of aviation safety.' These are fairly strong things to say about people who are performing a community function by representing the people of this country as board members on the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. It is a pretty strong accusation to make, without any substantial evidence to back it up, accusing them of putting their own self-interests ahead of the interests of aviation safety in this country. It is something that I think the minister may well regret in the future when he reflects on it. The opposition does not object to the content of the bill. It does not see a huge difference between four and six members of the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. If you look at the range of memberships of various equivalent boards, you will see that the numbers vary quite a bit, that there is no golden or perfect number, and that both four and six members are equally acceptable. So the notion of increasing the size of the board does not attract any criticism from the opposition; it does not see that there is any optimum number for members of the board. Wednesday, 26 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2941 Equally, the opposition does not object to the notion that the two additional places should be used to place additional expertise or aviation industry background on the board. The opposition believes that such boards should have a balance between generalist expertise, such as that of some of the existing members of the board, and specialist expertise that is directly relevant to the area that is being regulated. A number of very interesting statements have been made by the minister on this issue. I think it is important to take a more sober view of the issue. For example, as I cited in the House yesterday, I doubt whether there are too many directors of BHP who grew up shovelling coal into steel furnaces or working as iron workers. I note also, as I did yesterday, that the new head of the transport department, Dr Hawke, is in fact a geneticist by trade. I think it was an excellent appointment and it illustrates that there are many positions in the hierarchy in the public sector that should have a generalist rather than a direct specialist involved in the area. In the case of the CASA board, I believe there should be a mix: some aviation specialists and some generalists. It is also important to mention, as the minister as failed to do, that one of the three members he says has no expertise in aviation does, in fact, have very directly relevant expertise in system safety, and that is Dr Claire Pollock. She studied under Professor James Reason, who has developed the methodology which is most widely acknowledged as the appropriate methodology for analysing disasters such as major airline crashes and who, I understand, headed the investigation into the Manchester plane disaster some years ago. So it is quite clear that one of those three does have directly relevant expertise. Given that the function of the CASA board is not to go out and inspect the planes or do the hands-on work of the authority-which, quite appropriately, should be done by people with the directly relevant expertise-the function of the board is to ensure that the authority fulfils its obligations under the act of parliament which governs it. That is something which, I would have thought, a judge would be fairly well qualified to do, being somebody with substantial legal expertise. That supervisory role of the board, in a general sense, is quite different from the function of actually performing the task of safety regulation and administration that the authority itself does. On the substance of the legislation, the opposition does not object to the notion of the appointment of one of the board members as the deputy chair. From time to time, having a deputy chair will be of some consequence. A quick examination of similar boards, such as that of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, indicates that most similar boards under the Commonwealth umbrella have a position of deputy chair. There is some controversy with respect to the prospect that the minister is endeavouring to create a position on the board for Dick Smith and, in doing so, to force out the existing board members by backdoor means because he is unable to do so by the front door. The second reading amendment which I hereby move is specifically designed to deal not only with that situation but also with the broader concern that the opposition has with respect to people who have a partisan position in the aviation industry being appointed to the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. The opposition does not have any objection to Dick Smith as an individual. In fact, I have not met Mr Smith, although I have had several discussions with Mr Munro of the same organisation. So far, the indications are that I would probably agree with Mr Smith and Mr Munro on one or two issues. I certainly disagree with them on a number of others. The fact is, regardless of Mr Smith's position on any of these issues and whether he is right or wrong, MC 2942 MAIN COMMITIEE Wednesday, 26 June 1996 he is a very high profile and quite controversial campaigner within the aviation industry, campaigning on issues that directly relate to CASA's jurisdiction. In my view-regardless of whether I agree lOOper cent, or disagree 100 per cent, with him on those issues-it is inappropriate for anybody who plays or has recently played such a role to be appointed to the CASA board. Somebody who has been a highly partisan political lobbyist representing a section of the industry-regardless of who that might be-should not be appointed to what is basically an umpire's position. It is perfectly reasonable to have people with a background and expertise in the industry, as I indicated before, and I think Mr Molloy is a good example of that. But I and the opposition do not believe that it is appropriate for people who have been strong campaigners and political lobbyists on issues related to CASA' s jurisdiction to be placed on the board. CAS A makes very difficult decisions and choices that affect people's lives and livelihoods. It would be inappropriate to have people on the board of CASA who have axes to grind. There is a serious risk that, if that occurs, the CASA board will tum into a battleground between competing interests in the aviation industry. This is another reason why it is appropriate to have at least some people on the board who do not come from the aviation industry itself, but have other relevant expertise. In summary, the opposition opposes any partisan advocate for any particular section of the aviation industry being represented directly on the CASA board. I should also make it clear that the opposition does not agree with the general position that Mr Smith has been associated with on what is termed 'affordable safety'. I will not repeat them today, but I will note the comments made-at pages 8,50, 73 and 75-by the coroner who investigated the Monarch crash, with respect to the 'affordable safety' philosophy and the impact that that had on the Civil Aviation Authority, as it then was. It is too early for me, as shadow minister for transport, to form conclusive views on the issue of to what extent the problems of the then Civil Aviation Authority were caused by that philosophy. In fact, it may be very difficult to form conclusive views at all, because these things are extremely complex. Certainly, the coroner's view was that that philosophy had a significant contributing impact on the Monarch crash, and I think we have to take some note of that. It is interesting that there is an inherent contradiction in the position of the minister on these issues. On one hand, he has been very strongly supportive of the agenda that Mr Smith and his organisation have put-for example, the overruling of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority on the question of electronic locater transmitters. So far, he has appeared to be very supportive, and that will be clearly evidenced if he does appoint Mr Smith to the board. On the other hand, he has taken a very strong and very vigorous position, particularly in opposition, with respect to the performance of the Civil Aviation Authority and then CASA, regarding rigorous safety enforcement. I would suggest to him that there is an inherent contradiction in those two points of view and that, at some point, that contradiction will hit home. I tum now very briefly in conclusion to the amendment that I gather has been circulated by the honourable member for Calare( Mr Andren). This is at least the third such one, I think I am correct in saying. One was from the honourable member for Kalgoorlie ( Mr Campbell), but they are all on the same issue; that is, giving the minister the capacity to dismiss the existing members of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority board. This particular amendment in effect gives the minister unrestricted power to dismiss the members of the board at any time, for no reason. The existing legislation specifies reasons, such as becoming of unsound mind Wednesday, 26 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2943 or bankruptcy and the like, which are usually included for dismissal of members of boards of statutory authorities. The amendment that has been moved by the member for Calare in effect would allow the minister unfettered power to dismiss board members. The opposition does not support this amendment; firstly, because it is directly targeted at removing existing board members where, as far as the opposition can see, there is no justification for doing so, since they have not done anything wrong in the discharge of their duties; and, secondly, particularly when the minister is pursuing another avenue which allows him to influence the composition of the board by adding two members. The opposition believes that this is completely unjustified in the specific circumstances. More importantly, there is a broader principle here, and that is the whole question of the relationship between statutory authorities and the government. If you have a situation where the minister can arbitrarily dismiss board members-all of them, at any time, and for no reason-you have to question why you have a statutory authority in the first place and why, in this case, you do not simply return to the old department of transport situation where the conduct of civil aviation safety regulation is directly under ministerial control; because the net effect of having board members who are subject to instant dismissal is the same. If you apply this principle across the board to other statutory authorities, and if you do it here, you have to ask why you are not doing it elsewhere. If you apply it across the board, then you effectively negate one of the key components of the whole concept of a statutory authority which is, to some extent, to depoliticise the process that it is involved with and the obligations that it is there to discharge; to remove the political process a bit from that, without severing ultimate lines of accountability but still allowing the proper administration of that area to occur without direct day-to-day political interference. That is the whole purpose. to refer to the anticipated amendment, but it is drawing a long bow to go into the detail, so I would ask him to come back to the matter being debated. I do not mind him referring to the amendment, but it is a bit beyond the pale to go into the details of it at this stage. respect to the amendment. For the reasons associated with both the specific situation in this instance and the general principle of the damage that it would do to the structure of statutory authorities and their relationship with the government, the opposition will oppose the amendment. My final comments relate to the way the minister is dealing with the question of the current performance of the staff of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. It seems pretty clear that the staff of the former Civil Aviation Authority, several years ago, were derelict in their duty in a number of cases. You only have to read the coroner's report into the Monarch crash to see that that fairly clearly was the case. However, the minister has made a number of fairly flamboyant and rather reckless statements in recent times suggesting that this sort of conduct is continuing, that the same people are doing the same things. For example, in his statement yesterday, he said that he was concerned that the old culture still existed 'despite the change of name', that existing CAA officers felt 'somehow immune to the consequences of their own wrongdoing', and that the government would not be 'repeating the errors of the previous government in allowing that attitude to continue uncorrected.'

If you read the Australian constitution, you will find that aviation is one of the heads of power which is the responsibility of the federal government. All of the airstrips in the electorate of Kennedyevery single airport, with one exception, I think-are imposed upon the local authority. There is nothing in the constitution about local authorities running airports or aviation; but again we had the economic rationalists and a really vicious decision by the then federal government of Mr Hawke forcing these local authorities to take on these airstrips. The federal government said, 'We are pulling out. We are not going to put a single cent into these airstrips forever. So it is upon your head.' I argued very strongly in the Queensland cabinet that the Queensland government ought to tell the federal government to go to hell and, if any accidents occurred, it would be upon the head of the federal government. The federal government has had the responsibility of looking after this area placed upon it by the people of Australia. Some people may say, 'With economic rationalism and user pays, if you cannot pay your way out there, do not live out there.' Mr Deputy Speaker, they have put that proposition to us, and the net result of it has been that people out there have said, 'All right; we cannot live out here. We are moving.' Thirty-nine per cent of people in western Queensland have moved over the last 25 years, and they are running away just about as fast as their feet can carry them, thanks to the user-pays principle and the principles of the economic rationalists. But, unfortunately, they are taking with them the wealth of this nation. This nation's biggest export earning item in 1988 was wool, as it was for the 10 years prior to that-or neck and neck with coal, as it has been for all of our history. Half of our sheep herd has gone, and the numbers are falling dramatically right at this very moment. The cattle herd-the fifth biggest export earning item for this nation-is falling over. The difficulties placed upon the mining industry by the Native Title Act that has been legislated into existence by this place, and the enormous power given to the extreme element of the green movement in Australia, have dealt death blows to the mining industry as well. Because of the fringe benefits tax and because of the user-pays principle, there are very many things now in these areas that we are doing without. Let me come back to Mount Isa for one brief moment, because they are discussing industrial relations in the other place. Because of the fringe benefits tax and because of the government's policy of having high interest rates and a high Australian dollar, Mount Isa Mines has suffered enormous pain. The net result of that is that we lost our fly-ins. One of the great advantages of working in Mount Isa was having your annual free holiday to Brisbane. Even though many people would consider Mount MC 2948 MAIN COMMITfEE Wednesday, 26 June 1996 Isa a hostile living environment, I would not. It is my home. I love it, of course, and I enjoy it out there. But most people would say that living there is very difficult. So, when they lost the annual holiday flights, there was very strong persuasion and pressure put upon the residents of Mount Isa to simply leave. The population of Mount Isa has dropped from 30,000 to 20,000. Whether it is in the field of mining, which used to whip along at about six per cent growth per year and has now dropped down to about 0.6 per cent growth per year-most certainly under one per cent-or whether it is in the field of agriculture, which is down from about three per cent annual growth to about 0.2 per cent annual growth over the last four years, you can see that people are moving out. In real terms, these industries are declining. The last time. I looked, I found that 93 per cent of the nation's entire export earnings comes from these industries. But if you remove the services irom these areas you will deal body blows to these industries. I could stand here all day and argue, if you want to go into true economic rationalism. If we really were fair dinkum about figuring out what was paying for itself and what was not, we would close down Sydney and move the population out to the Mount Isas, the Longreaches and the Hughendens. If you were being fair dinkum about economic rationalism obviously the only places where this country is internationally competitive is in those fields. Our export earnings indicate quite clearly that 93 per cent of our income comes from those areas. I come here today with a great deal of bitterness. When I land in Mount IsaI know thatlike all of my fellow citizens in an area where my own family have lived for over 100 yearswe live in very great jeopardy. My grandaddy was one of the original 26 investors in Qantas. The reason they invested in Qantas was-and here I want to refer to Reverend Flynn who founded the Royal Flying Doctor Service-to bring a mantle of safety to the outback. Again, my grandaddy helped the Royal Flying Doctor Service greatly and was a great admirer of Dr Flynn. Every day that goes by the economic rationalists are removing that mantle of safety. value, and native title and fringe benefits tax, we might profit from some discussion of the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill, which is before the House. That bill provides for the expansion of the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority by adding two non-executive members and empowering the minister to appoint a member as deputy chairperson. As the opposition spokesman, the member for Melbourne ( Mr Tanner) indicated, he is not opposing the bill, but he has moved an amendment arising from our concerns about the nature of those who should be on the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. We would again invite the minister, as we have done before, to give an undertaking that he will not appoint anyone who is an active political lobbyist on behalf of one section of the aviation community. We make the point that aviation has numerous factions and interests which are often in intense disagreement on major industrial issues, including safety regulation. If the board is to be a battleground for competing interests within the industry, I believe that the consequences for the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and aviation safety could be disastrous. We have noted that the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association has been waging a bitter battle against the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, and that its position has essentially been partisan in relation to all this. We have some concerns about that position being given undue authority.

theText: They are the people involved. They are the people whose lives are at risk!Wednesday, 26 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2949 go on to describesilence. He will do the House and the other speaker the courtesy of doing the same. the point of view of the recent inquiry into civil aviation safety, Plane safe, produced by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure as recently as December of last year. That was an inquiry into aviation safety in the commuter and general aviation sectors. ThenI want to look at this subject from the point of view of a member of parliament responsible for the safety of constituents adjacent to an airport, the Essendon airport. If we look at the inquiry into aviation safety, we can see that the report has discussed the concept of affordable safety. The committee has expressed some concerns about that concept which I would endorse. My own view is that it is a very dangerous concept because it is a euphemism for market forces and deregulation which, in an area of safety standards, simply will not work. The committee at paragraph 2.50 suggested that the concept of affordable safety which was popularised by Dick Smith had within it the concept of accountability to the aviation industry and that that approach could indeed be an explanation for some of the shortcomings of the then Civil Aviation Authority in the performance of its duties. It went on further to say that the Civil Aviation Authority was never captured by the aviation industry; on the contrary, the regulator offered itself as a willing captive. It went on to note submissions it had received that safety standards may well have been reduced. Arising out of this concept of affordable safety, you had Alan Terrell giving the opinion that safety standards had been reduced as a result of deregulation, devolution and delegation to industry commercialisation. He expressed the view that the safety position in general aviation may already be below an acceptable level if the insurance statistics showing a 40 per cent increase in general aviation claims between the early 1990s and the late 1980s could be translated into operational events. You had the submission from the Australian Licensed Aircraft Engineers Association indicating that, in their view, safety standards had fallen disastrously. The committee went on to disregard the evidence given by Dick Smith because they pointed out that he had included balloon fatalities and excluded crew fatalities, which seemed quite extraordinary. They went on to conclude that there was some hard evidence of a decline in safety in the area of charter operations, although they said there was no hard evidence to show a deterioration of safety in other sectors of general aviation. They also made some points about the possibility of competition within the industry leading to lower safety standards. In chapter 5 they referred to destructive competition. The Industry Commission noted that greater competition might provide an incentive for some operators not to fully comply with safety requirements and that there may be a case for strengthening enforcement procedures. The committee concluded that some preconditions existed for avoiding essential maintenance which endangered safety. They proposed a couple of steps to try and address what they described as destructive competition: the publication of serious deficiency reports and special surveillance of charter operators concerning their business background, aircrew skills and aircraft conditions.

theText: I want to consider the issues of civil aviation safety firstly fromMC 2950 MAIN COMMITIEE Wednesday, 26 June 1996 Chapter7 of this inquiry into aviation safety dealt with the issue of bogus parts. A senior airworthiness inspector with the Civil Aviation Authority indicated to the committee that the use of bogus parts was entrenched and a well-known feature of the industry, and that the Bureau of Air Safety Investigations had data that in the last 10 years there had been three cases where bogus parts were clearly a factor in aviation incidents. There was some concern expressed within the committee on the issue of bogus parts. The committee also expressed a view about emergency locater transmitters and said that those transmitters might be phased in. Since charter operators carry more people than other areas of general aviation, the committee therefore said that emergency locater transmitters perhaps could be installed in these aircraft first because the benefits of installing them were likely to be larger. We have that background of concern about aviation safety being expressed by the House of Representatives standing committee. It is also the case for people in the electorate that I represent, the electorate of Wills, that there is considerable concern about the aviation safety standards applying at Essendon Airport. Most recently, we have had a report released on the December 1993 crash of a 1948 Dove aircraft, from the Essendon Airport, into five houses in Gilbertson Street, Essendon. My concern is that this long-awaited report has failed to pursue recommendations which would guarantee that such a crash would not recur. The report identifies the failure of the Dove's right engine, caused by failure of that engine's fuel control unit pumps, as the key cause of the crash. But its interim recommendation that all such fuel control unit pumps be inspected was rejected by the Civil Aviation Authority. The bureau meekly accepted this. I would say that the Civil Aviation Authority's justifications for rejecting that recommendation were simply not good enough. They said, in the first place, that the cause of the fuel pump failure had not been adequately determined. That, in my view, is all the more reason for checking pumps in other planes. Their second justification for not implementing this recommendation was the 'operational and financial burden on Australian DH-104 operators'. In my view, that surely must not be allowed to override the safety of aircraft travellers and those who live near airports. It is an expression of that concept of 'affordable safety' which I referred to earlier and which I think is absolutely unacceptable. The other thing the report does is identify the failure of the landing gear to retract when the pilot first selected it as a key reason that the plane was unable to fly with its remaining engine. It was a twin-engine plane, so one engine failed and it was not able to fly with the other engine because the landing gear did not retract first time around. The report went on to state: periodic checking of the adjustment of the landing gear selection system is therefore a critical practice that was not addressed in the systems of scheduled maintenance. Yet the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation made no recommendation for landing gear maintenance to include this check. You would expect that a crash of this seriousness would at least lead to changes designed to prevent a recurrence. But, instead of receiving recommendations to address these problems, residents living around Essendon Airport are told that they are going to have to live with a lower safety standard than applies at, for example, Tullamarine. The report states: if light aircraft are to be operated in a realistic manner, a level of safety lower than that present in large aircraft must be tolerated. Wednesday, 26 June 1996 MAIN COMMITTEE MC 2951 It also says: During take off there is an accepted risk period within which, should an engine failure occur, an accident might result. That period is up to 25 seconds. If that is the case, clearly the area of Essendon, which is completely surrounded by housing, is hardly the place for these risks. My view is that the situation is particularly serious concerning charter aircraft, because, as the report indicates: No guarantees are provided regarding their ability to fly with one engine inoperative. The Certificate of Airworthiness simply doesn't require it. If that is to continue to be the case, we should certainly not have charter flights operating out of Essendon. On that count I, and the electorate that I represent, express considerable concern about safety standards. I express some concern because the minister-who, as a shadow minister, had a lot to say about aviation safety, much of which was of interest to me, representing the electorate that I do-has a mandate to improve safety standards, not a mandate to allow safety standards to slip. I would raise some concern at the decision that the minister took, going back a couple of weeks, to override the Civil Aviation Safety Authority on the emergency locater transmitter issue. This was only a first issue and a first step, I guess. Nevertheless, it is not a happy precedent that the minister has chosen to ignore the view of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and to impose his own position on that issue. I express some concern about that. I note that the minister made a lot out of safety issues when he was in opposition, with the Monarch crash and so on. These are important issues, and I used to share some of his concerns, because it was certainly my view that the Federal Airports Corporation and the management at Essendon Airport had always had a 'she'll be right, mate' attitude and were forever playing down issues of aviation safety, and that they were not up-front with me. I remember that, when the de Havilland Dove crashed in December 1993, I and everyone else who visited the site on that night thought, 'That's it, then. The airport will surely close now; but look at the terrible cost in terms of the damage that it has done.' I and others were amazed when the aviation authorities commenced glossing over this incident. And this is still happening. We had the owner-operator and pilot of that plane, Mr Rudge, writing to a local paper and saying that the inquiry showed that he was not to blame. I just wonder what he thinks happened: that the plane fell out of the sky by itself? We had a school of criminologists in the 1970s who used to say that society was to blame. So you may wonder whether Mr Rudge thinks that society is to blame for the crash. Even as recently as Saturday 15 June, just a week and a bit ago, we had eyewitness accounts of another near miss at Essendon Airport. Once again, the aviation authority was saying, 'Oh, this wasn't too bad.' The spokeswoman for Airservices Australia was reported as saying that a Beechcraft Skipper was flying south on its final approach to runway 17 when a Piper Cherokee approached from the east. The Cherokee pilot had been instructed by the control tower to follow the Skipper. She said: There was a student pilot in the Cherokee who turned on to the base leg without allowing enough distance to follow the Skipper. MC 2952 MAIN COMMITTEE Wednesday, 26 June 1996 The Skipper then had to make a go-around and he would have pulled out of the situation to allow the aircraft that was supposed to let him in to land first. According to eye witnesses, it was quite a serious incident, which occurred directly above de Havilland Avenue in Strathmore. It is most unsatisfactory from the point of view of local residents to have the procession of accidents and incidents that we have had at Essendon Airport and to have, once again, this being fobbed off by aviation authorities. We even have the situation where there is a fresh proposal for pilot training at Essendon Airport, with a proposal to establish a pilot training scheme for overseas pilots. Yet the near miss which occurred just a week and a half ago arose in relation to a trainee pilot, and it certainly heightens the case against the pilot school being established there. In conclusion, the mandate of the transport minister is to improve air safety in this country. It will not happen by kowtowing to the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association. It will not happen by going with the concept of affordable safety, which is a pseudonym for market forces and the absence of the necessary regulation 'of safety standards. It will not happen by appointing, for example, Dick Smith to the board. These sorts of things would greatly concern both the opposition and people in my electorate.
